title: Passwords generated using short wordlist resulting in low entropy Variant 6
description:
Using complex passwords (those with high entropy) helps to resist brute forcing attacks, and is especially important in systems where there is no Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) available and where password expiration is not frequent.

The wordlist found was 177 short words, which is then used to generate passwords by combining a random selection of three of the words.

The word list in use for generating passwords is considered short. This results in relatively easy to brute force passwords being generated for users.
impact:
The likelihood of this being exploited is high, as the list is contained in a public GitHub repository. Even if that were not the case the self registration process could be exploited to generate a large number of passwords automatically, exposing the word list.  Furthermore, the level of entropy is low enough even without the word list being exposed that brute forcing it would still be relatively trivial.

The impact of this vulnerability is difficult to quantify.  For general users, it is considered low.  However, this service is available throughout the agency and therefore has high-profile users as well.  The nature of some of these users makes the impact of a successful attack high.
mitigation:
Use a substantially larger wordlist for generating user passwords.  This word list must be at least 10,000 words.

Add additional entropy to the password generation process, for example, consider using four words instead of three. Instead, consider using some numbers and symbols, though this must be completed with accessibility and usability in mind.

Ensure that passwords expire.  Choose an expiry period that suits the system and user context.  For example, it is recommended that every 30 days is too short, but anything more than 1 year is likely too long.
